awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: NSFGEO-NERC: The Origin of Aeolian Dunes (TOAD)
awd_abstract_narration:
Aeolian (wind-blown) sand dunes occupy 10% of the Earth's surface, both in vast desert sand seas and as important natural defenses against flooding along coasts. Despite extensive study of mature dunes, the question of "How do wind-blown dunes form?" remains unanswered, yet it is central to understanding dunes as major geological units, particularly given their increasing occurrence in desert regions of the United States and their adverse impact on water and vegetation supplies. This research will examine the key inter-relationships between airflow, surface properties, changes in sand transport and bedform shape that lie behind a meaningful understanding of how nascent dunes emerge. The project will promote international collaboration among the United States, the United Kingdom, and Namibia. It will generate public educational materials about desert landscapes and geomorphology, foster partnerships with National Parks in both the United States and Namibia, and provide quality scientific training and field experience to students.

Field monitoring of surface properties and bedform change at high resolution will be performed at three carefully chosen locations of known dune development. Complementary laboratory experiments will enable accurate characterization of flow very close to the 3D surface of modelled dunes that, together with the field datasets, will drive a computer model to test the sensitivity of dune initiation and growth to different controls in a range of environmental conditions in deserts, coasts and on other planets. In concert, this approach represents an opportunity to overcome an enduring plateau for understanding the origins of one of the major terrestrial landform systems. The team will work with staff at Great Sand Dunes National Park in the United States and the Namib-Naukluft National Park in Namibia to create broadly accessible public engagement materials. At a dedicated impact workshop in Gobabeb, Namibia, the team will showcase to interested local Namibian and international delegates the project findings and how these findings could be used to influence societal and economic issues. The project will engage undergraduate and graduate students in Namibia and give them valuable experience that could inspire them to pursue careers in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sand dunes are a common feature in many of the worlds dry regions — from cold polar environments to hot deserts, as well as along coastlines and beaches. Covering tens of thousands of square kilometers on the Earths surface, terrestrial dunes are both an important and dynamic part of Earths environment. Through their stratigraphic record, the deposits of aeolian dunes can also provide critical information concerning past climates. Dune fields can also switch between active and inactive states, as controlled by climate and groundwater table, and their development can therefore have major implications for land degradation, dust emission, and human infrastructure in desert environments. Furthermore, dunes have also been observed on other planets, such as Mars and Venus, and thus are a key source of information concerning the atmospheric conditions and surfaces of these planetary bodies. However, our ability to interpret such data is dependent upon understanding the formation of dunes and their dynamics on Earth. Although aeolian (i.e. wind-formed) sand dunes have been studied for many decades, and we possess a good understanding of the dynamics of mature, developed dunes and dune fields, far less is known about the processes causing the initiation of dunes and their early-stage development. The principal aim of this research was thus to address this gap in knowledge and improve our understanding of how sand dunes are initiated and then develop towards mature sand dunes. Understanding these processes could aid development of strategies to mitigate challenges such as land degradation, dust emission and the impacts of dunes on human infrastructure in desert areas across the globe

Past studies have speculated on the role of initial small deposits of sand that then interact with the atmospheric wind flow, but these ideas have not been tested due to the very small size of the initial deposits and the extreme difficulty in measuring these, and their associated flow fields, in the natural environment. The present approach therefore aimed to shed light on these processes through targeted laboratory experiments, measuring the flow over representative scaled ?protodunes?. This work has complemented new field experiments conducted by our collaborators studying similar dune forms in natural environments. 

Protodunes in nature are usually only a few centimeters in height, and differ notably from mature dunes by exhibiting a ?reverse morphological asymmetry?. This means that the gentler upflow (windward) slope and steeper downwind (lee) side slope characteristic of mature dunes are reversed in their orientation on a protodune, such that their steepest slope is on their upstream side. However, it is a challenge to measure the flow field around sand dunes in the field, especially for small-scale bedforms. Therefore, the critical role of the laboratory experiments conducted herein was to measure flow and turbulence associated with dune morphologies represented by scaled-down dune models in a unique flow channel. This flow facility takes advantage of a refractive-index-matching technique, wherein the acrylic objects (models) within the channel possess the same refractive index as the fluid moving over them, effectively rendering them invisible such that optical flow measurements can capture the critical near-surface regions of the flow relevant for sediment transport. The flow was measured using particle image velocimetry, an optical technique wherein passive tracer particles in the flow are illuminated with a laser sheet and their reflections, as imaged with a camera or multiple cameras, are used to track fluid motion at many points in space. Dune models were fabricated using idealized morphologies based on protodune topographies measured in the field, with the goal of reproducing their key physical characteristics. Great care was taken to ensure similarity between the laboratory flow and the atmospheric flow within which natural dunes are formed. 

Data indicate strong perturbations to flow over the protodunes induced by the gentle topography of the initial dunes, and to a similar relative degree as that found over mature dunes, despite their low-angled slopes. The shape of the dune crest was found to be an important factor in the development of flow perturbations, and only in the case with the flattest crest was a maximal speed-up of flow, and reduction in turbulent stresses, found to occur upstream of the crest. Investigation of the logarithmic shape of the downstream component of velocity profile over the stoss sides (an important metric for quantifying shear stress over the dune surface) showed that, although the profile is strongly perturbed, a log-linear region exists, but is shifted vertically within the flow. A streamwise trend in surface shear stress is thus present, showing a behavior similar to the trends in mean velocity. Analysis of the growth of the velocity distribution on the upsteam stoss sides of the dunes, beginning at the dune toe, reveals a similar development for all dune shapes, despite clear differences in mean velocity and turbulent stress perturbations in their toe regions.
